fields: The {{c1::Asama-Sansō Jiken}} (浅間山荘事件) was a hostage crisis and police siege in 1972. The police rescue operation on the final day of the standoff was the first marathon live television broadcast in Japan, lasting 10 hours and 40 minutes. The incident began when five armed members of the United Red Army (URA), following a bloody purge that left fourteen members of the group plus one bystander dead, broke into a mountain lodge below Mount Asama, taking the wife of the lodge-keeper as a hostage.

{{c1::Pinku eiga (ピンク映画)}} in its broadest sense includes almost any Japanese theatrical film that includes nudity or deals with sexual content. This encompasses everything from dramas to action thrillers and exploitation film features.

An adaptation of the novel of the same name by Shintaro Ishihara, the older brother of cast member Yujiro Ishihara. Two brothers who fall in love with the same woman and the resulting conflict. 

It would later be known as a foundational work of the Sun Tribe genre.

{{c1::Rengō Sekigun}} (連合赤軍) -  United Red Army - was a militant communist organization that operated in Japan between July 1971 and March 1972. The United Red Army had 29 members and lost 14 by killing them in less than a year. The URA came to a sudden end with the Asama-Sanso incident.

全学連 - {{c1::Zengakuren}} is an abridgement of 全日本学生自治会総連合 - Zen Nihon Gakusei Jichikai Sō Rengō, which literally means "All-Japan Student Self-Government Associations League", founded in 1948. Notable for organizing protests and marches, it has been involved in Japan's anti-Red Purge movement, the anti-military base movement, the anti-Security Treaty movement, and the struggle against the construction of Narita Airport.
Who is the right-wing politician and author of the novel Kurutta kajitsu (狂った果実), Crazed Fruit, 1956, here in a photo with Mishima?
Shintaro Ishihara (石原 慎太郎, born 30 September 1932)

note_models.name: Basic

fields: 在日韓国人 ({{c1::Zainichi Kankokujin}}) are ethnic Koreans who have permanent residency status in Japan or who have become Japanese citizens and whose immigration to Japan originated before 1945 or who are descendants of those immigrants.

{{c1::Seishun eiga}} (青春映画), alias teen film, is a film genre targeted at teenagers and young adults by the plot being based on their special interests, such as coming of age, attempting to fit in, bullying, peer pressure, first love, teen rebellion, conflict with parents, and teen angst or alienation.

Direct-to-video or straight-to-video - the release of a film, TV series, short or special to the public immediately on home video formats rather than a theatrical release or television broadcast - is also called {{c1::Vシネマ}}
In its broadest sense, {{c1::Kaidan}} (怪談) refers to any ghost story or horror story, but it has an old-fashioned ring to it that carries the connotation of Edo period Japanese folktales.

{{c1::Jidaigeki}} (時代劇) is a genre of film, television, video game, and theatre in Japan. Literally meaning "period dramas", they are most often set during the Edo period of Japanese history, from 1603 to 1868.
{{c1::Yūrei}} (幽霊) are figures in Japanese folklore analogous to the Western model of ghosts.

{{c1::Yōkai}} (妖怪) are a class of supernatural monsters and spirits in Japanese folklore, with mutable characteristic, from malevolent and mischievous entities to those who are considered to bring good fortune.

{{c1::Onryō}} (怨霊) refers to a ghost (yūrei) believed to be capable of causing harm in the world of the living, injuring or killing enemies, or even causing natural disasters to exact vengeance to "re-address" the wrongs it received while alive.
{{c1::Oni}} (鬼) is a kind of yōkai, demon, ogre, or troll in Japanese folklore. They are typically portrayed as hulking figures with one or more horns growing out of their heads.
({{c1::お化け - Obake}}) are a class of yōkai. Literally, the terms mean a thing that changes, referring to a state of transformation or shapeshifting.

By the late 1970s a considerable number of {{c3::じしゅえいが}} (自主映画) - Self-Produced Films had been made by young directors in Japan, and the {{c2::Pia Film Festival}} was founded specifically to support this new area of filmmaking. Much of this new work came from filmmaking clubs in high schools and universities, {{c1::Eiga Kenkyukai or Eiken}} (映画研究会).
{{c1::Giri}} (義理) is a Japanese value roughly corresponding to "obligation", or even "burden of obligation". It is defined as "to serve one's superiors with a self-sacrificing devotion".
{{c1::Ninjō}} (人情), "human emotion or compassion", is human feeling that complements and opposes inescapably the value of giri, or social obligation, within the Japanese worldview.

In the 1970s, just as moviegoers were getting tired of the ninkyo films, a new breed of yakuza films emerged, the 実録映画 - {{c1::Jitsuroku eiga}}, "actual record films". These portrayed post-war yakuza not as honorable heirs to the samurai code, but as ruthless, treacherous street thugs living for their own desires. Many were based on true stories, and filmed in a documentary style with shaky camera.

A subset of Yakuza films known as 仁侠映画 - {{c1::Ninkyo eiga}} or "chivalry films" began to thrive in the 1960s. Most were created by the Toei studio and produced by Koji Shundo, who became close with actual yakuza before becoming a producer, and despite his denial, is said to have been one himself. Set in the Meiji and Taishō eras, the kimono-clad yakuza hero of ninkyo films was always portrayed as a stoic honorable outlaw torn between the contradictory values of giri (duty) and ninjo (personal feelings).

Plastics salesman Oshima disappeared without a word to anyone, and has been missing for two years. The director and his crew follow Oshima's fiancé Yoshie and actor Shigeru Tsuyuguchi as they investigate the disappearance.
tags: 日本アート・シアター・ギルド

fields:
It is the first film in Yoshida's trilogy of Japanese radicalism. Although the film is a biography of anarchist Sakae Ōsugi, the director stated that he didn't focus on him as a historical character per se:
Historical estimation only enlightens the past, and not the future [...] Ōsugi spoke of free love, which has the power to destroy the monogamous structure, then the family, and finally the state [...] It was because of this crime of the imaginary  that the state massacred Osugi. Osugi was someone who envisioned a future.
tags: 日本アート・シアター・ギルド

fields: An {{c1::エクスプロイテーション映画}} is a film that attempts to succeed financially by exploiting current trends, niche genres, or lurid content. These are generally low-quality "B movies", sometimes attracting critical attention and cult followings.

A young man breaks into a nurses' rooming house and one-by-one kills off the nurses therein.


Based on the mass murder spree of Richard Speck in 1966, who tortured and murdered eight student nurses from South Chicago Community Hospital.
The complete idiomatic expression of the title would be 白衣の天使 - はくいのてんし, that is nurse as "angel in white".

{{c1::Art Theatre Guild (ATG)}} was a film production company in Japan that started in 1961 and ran through to the mid-1980s, releasing mostly Japanese New Wave films. Some of the early films released by the company include Shōhei Imamura's A Man Vanishes (1967), Nagisa Oshima's Diary Of A Shinjuku Thief (1968) and Death by Hanging (1968), Toshio Matsumoto's masterpiece Funeral Parade of Roses (1969).

Transgender actor Pîtâ gives an astonishing performance as Eddie, hostess at Bar Genet – where she’s ignited a violent love-triangle with reigning drag queen Leda for the attentions of club owner Gonda.
One of Japan’s leading experimental filmmakers bends and distorts time, and freely mixes documentary interviews, Brechtian film-within-a-film asides, Oedipal premonitions of disaster, his own avant-garde shorts, and even on-screen cartoon balloons. Funeral Parade of Roses is a celebration of youth and subcultures, a condemnation of intolerance, and a one-of-kind cinematic experience.
The title is a pun, as "rose" (bara) in Japanese can have a similar meaning to "pansy" in English slang.
tags: 日本アート・シアター・ギルド

fields: Also known as Pastoral Hide and Seek is a young boys' coming of age tale set in a strange, carnivalesque village becomes the recreation of a memory that the director has twenty years later.
Pastoral: To Die in the Country
死す(る) is an archaic term for 死ぬ
tags: 日本アート・シアター・ギルド

fields: {{c1::Sakoku}} (鎖国), "closed country", was the isolationist foreign policy of the Japanese Tokugawa shogunate under which, for more than two centuries (1639-1854), relations and trade between Japan and other countries were severely limited, nearly all foreign nationals were barred from entering Japan and common Japanese people were kept from leaving the country.
水子供養 - {{c1::Mizuko Kuyō}} meaning "water child memorial service", is a Japanese ceremony for those who have had a miscarriage, stillbirth, or abortion.

{{c1::Ubasute}} (姥捨て) is the supposed rare, old practice of senicide in Japan, whereby an infirm or elderly relative was carried to a mountain, or some other remote, desolate place, and left there to die. Is the subject of legend, but does not seem ever to have been an actual custom.
被爆者 or 被曝者 - {{c1::Hibakusha}} - "person affected by exposure [to a bomb]" is a word designating the people affected by the 1945 atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki.

{{c1::アングラ}}, an abbreviation of the Japanese phrase "underground theater", {{c2::andaaguraundo engeki}} (アンダーグラウンド演劇), was a Japanese avant-garde theater movement in the 1960s and 1970s that reacted against the Brechtian modernism and formalist realism of postwar Shingeki theater in Japan to stage anarchic "underground" productions in tents, on street corners, and in small spaces that explored themes of primitivism, sexuality, and embodied physicality. A major figure in the Angura movement was Shūji Terayama.

The formal term used for units carrying out suicide attacks during 1944–1945 is {{c2::tokubetsu kōgekitai}} (特別攻撃隊), which literally means "special attack unit". This is usually abbreviated to {{c1::tokkōtai}} (特攻隊).
{{c1::Shinjū}} (心中) in common parlance is used to refer to any group suicide of persons bound by love, typically lovers, parents and children, and even whole families.
The {{c1::kuroko}} (黒衣)  are stagehands in traditional Japanese theatre, who dress all in black. They move scenery and props on stage, aiding in scene changes and costume changes.

A harsh young man seduces a freeloading young woman and eventually takes advantage of her knack for hitch-hiking to rob middle-class men. 

The director was already beginning to explore the themes he would soon become celebrated for: a focus on youth and on 'outsiders', and critical deconstructions of more stereotypical imagery in Japanese cinema.

Muraki is a Yakuza hitman just released from prison. At an illegal gambling parlor, he finds himself drawn to a mysterious young woman named Saeko. Though Saeko loses large sums of money, she asks Muraki to find games with larger and larger stakes. The two become involved in an intense mutually destructive relationship.
Shinoda chose the subject of yakuza as he felt the yakuza world is the only place where a Japanese ceremonial structure is sustained.

{{c1::Iwanami Eiga Seisakusho}} (岩波映画製作所) was a Japanese film production company. Founded in 1950 by people associated with the Iwanami Shoten publisher, it mainly focused on producing educational films and public relations documentaries. Younger filmmakers later formed the Blue Group ({{c2::Ao no Kai}}) to discuss and debate documentary and cinema, and from their members emerged several of Japan's prominent postwar fiction and documentary film directors and cinematographers, including Shinsuke Ogawa and Noriaki Tsuchimoto.

Born in a rural farming village in 1918, Tomé survives decades of Japanese social upheaval, as well as abuse and servitude at the hands of various men. Yet the director, ever the cinematic “entomologist,” refuses to make a victim of her, instead observing Tomé (played by the extraordinary Sachiko Hidari) as a fascinating, pragmatic creature of twentieth-century Japan. A portrait of opportunism and resilience in three generations of women.
The title is literaly Entomological Chronicles of Japan
{{c1::Zoku}} (族) is a Sino-Japanese term meaning tribe, clan, or family. As a suffix it has been used extensively within Japan to define subcultural phenomena.

Eiji Okada plays an amateur entomologist who has left Tokyo to study an unclassified species of beetle found in a vast desert. When he misses his bus back to civilization, he is persuaded to spend the night with a young widow (Kyoko Kishida) in her hut at the bottom of a sand dune. What results is one of cinema’s most unnerving and palpably erotic battles of the sexes, as well as a nightmarish depiction of everyday life as a Sisyphean struggle—an achievement that garnered the director an Academy Award nomination for best director.

{{c1::Anpo tōso}} (安保闘争) is the name given to a series of massive protests in Japan from 1959 to 1960, and again in 1970, against the US-Japan Security Treaty, allowing USA to maintain military bases on Japanese soil.

In this jazzy gangster film, reformed killer Tetsu’s attempt to go straight is thwarted when his former cohorts call him back to Tokyo to help battle a rival gang. Director Seijun Suzuki’s onslaught of stylized violence and trippy colors —an anything-goes, in-your-face rampage. A delirious highlight of the brilliantly excessive Japanese cinema of the sixties.

By 1971 the increased popularity of television had taken a heavy toll on the film industry and in order to remain profitable Nikkatsu turned to the production of {{c1::Roman Porno}} (from the French word for 'novel') and pinku eiga
When a thief is caught stealing form a book shop by one of its employees, the two embark on an unusual, erotic adventure.

The {{c1::Nikkatsu Kabushiki-gaisha}} (日活株式会社) is an entertainment company known for its film and television productions. It is Japan's oldest major movie studio, founded in 1912 during the silent film era.
An insecure guy falls in love with a young nude model. But his past sexual abuse hinders him of loving inhibitedly.
Nanami, The Inferno of First Love

初恋 = first love
地獄 = Hell
篇 = compilation of a text

One Zainichi Korean sued the Hitachi conglomerate in 1970 for “unhiring” him after they discovered his ancestry. Pak Chong Sok used his Japanese-sounding alias to sit for the company exam, but during routine paperwork upon being hired, he was required to submit proof of identification. Pak submitted his foreign registry card ({{c1::gaitōsho}}) and Hitachi immediately withdrew the offer of employment, openly stating that “We cannot hire a Korean.”

This movie is the apotheosis of the director thematic predilection: characters interact and engage with the natural world. More than a backdrop, the weather, especially its changes, accompany pivotal moments. A typhoon pauses the inevitable flow of life and brings kids, junior high school students, with all their fears and desires together.

Based on a children's novel of the same name written by Michio Takeyama, it tells the story of Japanese soldiers who fought in the Burma Campaign during World War II. A member of the group goes missing after the war, and the soldiers hope to uncover whether their friend survived, and if he is the same person as a Buddhist monk they see playing a harp. The film was among the first to show the losses of the war from a Japanese soldier's perspective.
